perturbation.original_text: 1.11 “Consumer” means, in relation to a product or service or market for a product or service, an individual who takes the product or service for primarily non-business and non-work purposes (even if, for the avoidance of doubt, that individual sometimes, as a secondary purpose, uses the product or service for their work or business).
perturbation.changed_text: 1.11 “Consumer” means, in relation to a product or service or market for a product or service, an individual who takes the product or service for any purposes (even if, for the avoidance of doubt, that individual sometimes, as a secondary purpose, uses the product or service for their work or business).
perturbation.explanation: The original definition of "Consumer" specifies usage primarily for "non-business and non-work purposes." The modified definition broadens this to "any purposes", directly conflicting with the original intent and creating uncertainty. This could impact how consumer-specific clauses, such as those related to data privacy or marketing restrictions, are interpreted and enforced.

perturbation.original_text: 1.2 “Affiliate” means in relation to any Person, any Subsidiary or Holding Company, and any company in which such Person or any such Holding Company holds or Controls directly or indirectly not less than 30% of the issued share capital.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.2 “Affiliate” means in relation to any Person, any Subsidiary or Holding Company, and any company in which such Person or any such Holding Company holds or Controls directly or indirectly not less than 10% of the issued share capital.
perturbation.explanation: By changing '30%' to '10%', the definition of 'Affiliate' now contradicts established corporate law standards for determining affiliation through shareholding. Many jurisdictions use a higher threshold (like 20% or 25%) to signify significant influence or control. This conflicting definition could lead to disputes regarding which entities are bound by the 'Affiliate' provisions within the contract, especially concerning liability or non-compete clauses.

perturbation.original_text: 14.9 Independent Contractors. The parties to this Agreement acknowledge and agree that they are dealing with each other hereunder as independent contractors. Nothing contained in this Agreement shall be interpreted as constituting any party the joint venturer, employee or partner of the other party or as conferring upon any party the power of authority to bind another party in any transaction with third parties.
perturbation.changed_text: 14.9 Independent Contractors. The parties to this Agreement acknowledge and agree that they are dealing with each other hereunder as workers. Nothing contained in this Agreement shall be interpreted as constituting any party the joint venturer, employee or partner of the other party or as conferring upon any party the power of authority to bind another party in any transaction with third parties.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition clearly states "independent contractors." By changing 'independent contractors' to 'workers,' it creates ambiguity and potential conflict with labor laws. Some jurisdictions have specific legal tests (e.g., the 'ABC test' or 'economic realities' test) to determine whether a worker is an independent contractor or an employee. Simply labeling them as 'workers' without adhering to these tests can lead to misclassification and legal challenges.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Labor Law - Independent Contractor vs. Employee
